content: Emily Sheehan is a student at Monash University studying a Master’s in Business Analytics. She has completed a Bachelor of Commerce at the University of Melbourne, and is interested in learning more about artifical intelligence and how data can be used to solve real world problems.
summary: Emily Sheehan is a student at Monash University studying a Master’s in Business Analytics. She has completed a Bachelor of Commerce at the University of Melbourne, and is interested in learning more about artifical intelligence and how data can be used to solve real world problems.
title: Emily Sheehan

content:
吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Sed neque elit, tristique placerat feugiat ac, facilisis vitae arcu. Proin eget egestas augue. Praesent ut sem nec arcu pellentesque aliquet. Duis dapibus diam vel metus tempus vulputate.
summary: 吳恩達 is a professor of artificial intelligence at the Stanford AI Lab. His research interests include distributed robotics, mobile computing and programmable matter. He leads the Robotic Neurobiology group, which develops self-reconfiguring robots, systems of self-organizing robots, and mobile sensor networks.
title: 吳恩達

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
Introducing my Shiny App The purpose of my app is to enable users to develop insights on the state of Coronavirus in Australia through comparing data between chosen states over time.
My app is broken up into tabs to enhance its usability. There is an ‘About’ tab, a ‘How’ tab and an example tab detailing how I drew insights on Coronavirus using the app. This hopes to give the user a clear understanding on how to use the app, irrespective of their technological competence/capacity.
The ‘output’ tabs each contain a visualisation. The first has a map, the second has a line plot and the third has a comparison table.
To use the map, the user must input the states that they want to compare. It will generate a circle, and the size of the circle is dependent on the number of confirmed cases in that state to date. The user can click on the circle and it will give the exact number of confirmed cases in that state or territory. In the example below, I have chosen New South Wales and Victoria.
The user must choose a case type in addition to the previously selected states or territories to use the plot. Therefore the confirmed, recovered or daily death toll between chosen states or territories can be compared overtime. To produce the plot below I have chosen ‘confirmed’ as my case type. The plot can be ‘double-clicked’ to reveal a timeline of COVID-19 related events.
Finally, to use the comparison table the user must select a date or dates to compare in addition to the previously selected states/territories and case type. This will generate a table which will allow them to compare daily case numbers and total case numbers for the chosen case type. dates and areas. I chose the earliest and most recent date to generate the comparison table below.
 Self Review What did I do well? The three aspects of the app that I did well were the user input and plotly event aspect of the app, as well as the explanation on how to use the app.
I did the explanation aspect of the app well because I provided an example of how I derived insights and arrived at conclusions using the app.
The plotly event that I created allows the user to ‘double-click’ on the plot to reveal a timeline of events, as mentioned above. I think I did this well because the user can easily compare and link the timeline events to points in the plot and draw conclusions on whether the restrictions were an effective measure in controlling the case numbers (as an example).
My use of the input data to generate outputs was well done because it meant the user has complete freedom in the outputs they want to generate as every output depends on the inputs they want to use. ??
 What could I improve on? My comparison table could definitely be improved. For example, when ‘death’ is input the table and values change, however, the column headings are the same. In this context, the headings don’t make sense as they are titled ‘number of new cases’ and ‘total number of cases’. it would make more sense if they changed according to input and were titled ‘number of new deaths’ and ‘total number of deaths’.
In addition, I coded the title of the plot so that it would change according to input. This means that if the user selects ‘confirmed’ the title would change to ‘The number of confirmed COVID-19 cases’, and so on. However, when ‘death’ is selected the title changes to ‘The number of death COVID-19 cases’. This doesn’t make gramatical sense, however, the paste0 function did not have the capacity to change the whole title based on the selected case type. In hindsight, I should have used an ifelse statement to produce a better title.
 A plausible addition to my app I would like to update the map so that the circles change based on the case type chosen (as well as the states and/or territories chosen).
The main issue with this change is the map doesn’t delete circles if the input has been changed. For example, if I select New South Wales and Victoria, and then deselect Victoria, it won’t update the map. This means that if a case type is chosen and then changed, the map will layer the two case types which is problematic for comparison.
To overcome this problem, I have two approaches that I think would be feasible. The first would involve use the ifelse function and the second improving the use of the reactive function.
 An implausible addition to my app age group breakdown whos spreading the virus whos dying frm it
summary: A review on my Shiny App...
title: My Shiny App

content:
The First Wave The United Kingdom had its first case of COVID-19 on the 31st of January, 2020. On the 1st of March, they had 6 cases. On the 7th of March, they had 55 cases. Two weeks later, they had 1215 cases.
In early March, the Prime Minister was reluctant to ban mass gatherings as the modeling suggested it would have little benefit. Instead, the initial response was “based on science”, with Boris Johnson focusing on contact tracing and isolation of those exposed to COVID-19 (Hunter, 2020).
The U.K. Chief Scientist suggested herd immunity would be achieved if 60% or more of the population recovered from COVID-19 (Hunter, 2020). In this sense, the UK was striving towards attaining herd immunity while protecting the elderly and immunocompromised. A leading epidemiologist likened this approach to “a satire” (Hanage, 2020), as this would mean a high number of deaths and devastation across the country.
On March 16, the UK shifted their public policy instructing citizens to avoid mass gatherings, work from home if possible, avoid non-essential travel and isolate if they had symptoms. On March 20, all pubs, all restaurants and most schools were closed. Approximately three weeks later the number of COVID-19 cases began to peak.
 The Second Wave The number of new COVID-19 cases have steadily increased since pubs and restaurants have re-opened. In addition, there has been an increase in illegal parties, which is leading to high levels of transmission among young people (Rosney, 2020). Although the daily case numbers are still considerably lower than April, the graph below is clearly trending upwards and the attitudes of civilians are becoming an increasing threat.
This considered, the UK are on the brink of a second wave.
 Confirmed COVID-19 Cases in the UK Overtime Interactive display showing the confirmed number of COVID-19 cases in the UK since the 22nd of January, 2020.
 {"x":{"url":"/post/UK/2020-09-12-coronavirus-in-the-uk.en_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_confirmed-plot.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}  Confirmed Deaths from COVID-19 in the UK Overtime Interactive display showing the number of COVID-19 deaths in the UK since the 22nd of January, 2020.
 {"x":{"url":"/post/UK/2020-09-12-coronavirus-in-the-uk.en_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_death-plot.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}  References Hunter, D. J. (2020). Covid-19 and the stiff upper lip—The pandemic response in the United Kingdom. The New England Journal of Medicine. Retrieved from https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMp2005755
Hanage, W. (2020). I’m an epidemiologist. When I heard about Britain’s ‘herd immunity’coronavirus plan, I thought it was satire. The Guardian, 03–15.
Rosney, D. (2020, September 7). Coronavirus: Young people breaking rules risk ‘second wave’. BBC. Retrieved from https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-54056771
summary: How the United Kingdom continues to evolve and respond to the first and second wave of COVID-19.
title: Coronavirus in the UK

content:
Data Description The coronavirus data comprises of 7 variables and over 175,000 observations for a number of countries. The variables include; date, province, country, latitude, longitude, type of case (i.e. confirmed/recovered) and number of daily cases.
The raw data has been collected on a daily basis since the 22nd of January 2020 by John Hopkins University Center for Systems Science and Engineering. The sources for the raw data include; the World Health Organisation, the National Health Commission of the People’s Republic of China, the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control, the U.S Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, local media reports, 1point3acres, Worldometers.info, BNO, DXY and other state and national government health departments.
The raw data has been tidied and collated into a package titled coronavirus, which has subsequently been used for this analysis.
 An Explanation Coronavirus is the name given to a range of respiratory illnesses originating from the same family (Raoult et al., 2020). Each virus varies in its symptoms, with some strains being more fatal than others. Some of the viruses that belong to this family include; Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS-CoV), Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS-CoV) and COVID-19.
 A Comparison Since appearing in Saudi Arabia in 2012, MERS has spread to 27 countries resulting in a total of 2494 confirmed cases of MERS-CoV worldwide. Saudi Arabia was home to approximately 2102 infections, and had 780 deaths, resulting in a death rate of 37.11% (World Health Organisation, 2020).
 Table 1: Summary Statistics for New COVID-19 Cases in Saudi Arabia    Average New Cases per day  Maximum Number of New Cases per day  Total Number of Cases      1437.005  4919  275905     Since early 2020, there have been approximately 275905 cases of COVID-19 in Saudi Arabia and 2866, thus resulting in a death rate of 1.04%.
 Table 2: Summary Statistics for Deaths due to COVID-19 in Saudi Arabia    Average Deaths per day  Maximum Number of Deaths per day  Total Number of Deaths      14.92708  58  2866     The maximum number of new cases on any given day was 4919 cases, which is approximately 234.02% of the total number of MERS-CoV infections in Saudi Arabia over an 8-year period, emphasizing the magnitude of COVID-19. The average number of new infections per day is approximately 1437 cases, whilst the average number of recovered cases per day is approximately 1227 cases. The maximum number of recovered cases on a given day was 7718 cases.
 Table 3: Summary Statistics for Recovered COVID-19 Cases in Saudi Arabia    Average Recovered Cases per day  Maximum Number of Recovered Cases per day  Total Number of Recovered Cases      1227.385  7718  235658     Ultimately, the summary statistics and the interactive table suggest a clear difference in the prevalence of MERS-CoV and COVID-19. Although MERS-CoV is much more fatal with an alarmingly high death rate, COVID-19 is much more infectious.
 {"x":{"url":"/post/Saudi/2020-09-03-coronavirus-in-saudi-arabia.en_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_interactive-table-saudi.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}  References Bhaskar Karambelkar (2017). widgetframe: ‘Htmlwidgets’ in Responsive ‘iframes’. R package version 0.3.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=widgetframe
Hao Zhu (2020). kableExtra: Construct Complex Table with ‘kable’ and Pipe Syntax. R package version 1.2.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=kableExtra
Rami Krispin and Jarrett Byrnes (2020). coronavirus: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus COVID-19 (2019-nCoV) Dataset. R package version 0.3.0.9000. https://github.com/RamiKrispin/coronavirus
Raoult, D., Zumla, A., Locatelli, F., Ippolito, G., & Kroemer, G. (2020). Coronavirus infections: Epidemiological, clinical and immunological features and hypotheses. Cell Stress & Chaperones, 4(4), 66–75.
Wickham et al., (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software, 4(43), 1686, https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686
World Health Organisation. (2020, March 10). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV). Retrieved 4 September 2020, from https://www.who.int/emergencies/mers-cov/en/

title: Coronavirus in Saudi Arabia

content:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic  Academic | Documentation
 Features  Efficiently write slides in Markdown 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides Supports speaker notes Mobile friendly slides   Controls  Next: Right Arrow or Space Previous: Left Arrow Start: Home Finish: End Overview: Esc Speaker notes: S Fullscreen: F Zoom: Alt + Click  PDF Export: E   Code Highlighting Inline code: variable
Code block:
porridge = "blueberry" if porridge == "blueberry": print("Eating...")   Math In-line math: $x + y = z$
Block math:
$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$
 Fragments Make content appear incrementally
{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}} {{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}  Press Space to play!
One  Two  Three 
 A fragment can accept two optional parameters:
 class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS) weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears   Speaker Notes Add speaker notes to your presentation
{{% speaker_note %}} - Only the speaker can read these notes - Press `S` key to view {{% /speaker_note %}}  Press the S key to view the speaker notes!
 Only the speaker can read these notes Press S key to view    Themes  black: Black background, white text, blue links (default) white: White background, black text, blue links league: Gray background, white text, blue links beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links    night: Black background, thick white text, orange links serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links simple: White background, black text, blue links solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links   Custom Slide Customize the slide style and background
{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}} {{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}} {{< slide class="my-style" >}}   Custom CSS Example Let’s make headers navy colored.
Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:
.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask
 Documentation

title: Slides
